questions.text: The Ulnar and Humeral heads of the pronator teres muscle are marked. What is the X-marked nerve?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The median nerve passes between the two heads of the pronator teres muscle.

questions.text: A boy fell onto a sharp object and cut his deep radial nerve as it emerged from the supinator muscle. The artery joining it at this point was also injured. The injured artery is the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The deep radial nerve emerges from the supinator muscle and runs in the deep layer of the posterior forearm while running next to the posterior interosseous artery.

questions.text: In the process of doing an axillary lymph node dissection in a 50-year-old patient, the surgery resident cleans the space between the pectoralis major and minor muscles, in an attempt to remove all of the lateral pectoral lymph nodes. Upon recovery, it is noted that the patient's lower pectoralis major is paralysed. The nerve most likely injured is the:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The medial pectoral nerve (y) is the nerve that is most likely injured, as its injury leads to paralysis of the lower sternocostal portion of the pectoralis major muscle.

  • The medial pectoral nerve arises from the medial cord as shown in the image.
  • It pierces the pectoralis minor to reach the pectoralis major.
  • It is at risk during surgery between the pectoralis major and minor, especially when dissecting lymph nodes in the clavipectoral (deltopectoral) space.

Explanation for other options:

The medial pectoral nerve innervates the inferior part of pectoralis major and pectoralis minor, while the lateral pectoral nerve innervates the superior part of pectoralis major only. (Option C ruled out) These two nerves are named after their origin from two different cords of the brachial plexus.

The thoracodorsal nerve (which is also derived from the brachial plexus) innervates latissimus dorsi and is not involved with the pectoral muscles. (Option B ruled out)

The long thoracic nerve runs along the lateral thoracic wall on the surface of the serratus anterior and innervates the serratus anterior, not the pectoralis muscles. Injury leads to a winged scapula. (Option A ruled out)

questions.text: In lymphatic drainage of the breast, the major portion (about 75%) eventually enters which group of nodes?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Axillary lymph nodes drain the majority of lymph, with the Central Axillary Nodes being the highest lymphatic drainage.

  • The breast is divided into 4 quadrants.
  • Lymph from the outer upper and lower quadrants primarily goes to the axillary nodes.
  • First to the lateral axillary nodes, then to the central, and finally apical nodes.
  • Lymph from the inner quadrants drains to the parasternal nodes along the sternum.
  • Some lymph crosses the midline or passes inferiorly to the abdominal nodes.

questions.text: During a motorcycle accident, an 18-year-old male landed on the right lateral side of his rib cage with his right upper limb abducted. In the hospital, he was found to have "winging" of the right scapula as shown. Which nerve was likely damaged in the accident?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Injury to the long thoracic nerve (C5–C7) denervates the serratus anterior, leading to scapular winging due to unopposed action of the trapezius and rhomboids.

  • This nerve runs superficially along the lateral thoracic wall, making it vulnerable to injury from trauma, such as a blow to the lateral rib cage.
  • The nerve is also vulnerable during surgeries like mastectomy due to its superficial location.
  • Winging of the scapula at rest can be due to spinal accessory nerve palsy and fascio-scapulo-humeral dystrophy.y

Explanation for other options:

Accessory nerve (Option A): Innervates the trapezius and sternocleidomastoid; damage may cause shoulder droop, but not scapular winging.

Vagus nerve (Option C): A cranial nerve with no role in shoulder or scapular movement.

Lateral pectoral nerve (Option D): Innervates the pectoralis major; damage doesn't cause scapular winging.

questions.text: Upon finding a malignant tumour in the medial portion of the breast of a 40-year-old female, the surgeon began to search for the lymph nodes that would be the first ones reached by metastatic spread of cancer cells from this site. Which group(s) would have to be examined to determine whether metastasis had occurred?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Parasternal and pectoral lymph nodes that would be the first ones reached by metastatic spread of cancer cells from this site.

Lymphatic drainage of the breast:

  • Lateral quadrants primarily drain to the axillary lymph nodes, especially the pectoral group.
  • Medial quadrants of the breast drain to the parasternal (internal thoracic) nodes.

In this case, the tumour is located medially, so:

  • Parasternal nodes must be examined, as they directly drain the medial breast.
  • Pectoral nodes (a subgroup of axillary nodes) may also be involved due to lymphatic anastomoses.

Explanation for other options:

Parasternal and apical (Option B): Apical nodes are higher-order nodes; they receive drainage from central nodes, not directly from the medial breast.

Parasternal and lateral (Option C): The  Lateral group drains the upper limb and lateral breast.

Parasternal and central (Option D): Central nodes are downstream from pectoral nodes; they’re not the first to receive drainage from the medial breast.

questions.text: Match the following shoulder Muscles with their corresponding actions.
Which of the following structures is not closely related to the pectoralis minor muscle in the axilla and does not use it as an anatomical landmark?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The cephalic vein runs in the deltopectoral groove, superficial and lateral to the pectoralis minor, and is not related to it directly in the axilla.

Pectoralis minor serves as a key landmark in the axilla:

  • Cords of the brachial plexus are named based on their position relative to it. (Option B)
  • The lateral thoracic artery runs along or near its lateral border. (Option C)
  • The medial pectoral nerve pierces it to reach the pectoralis major. (Option D)

questions.text: During insertion of an IV cannula in the median cubital vein, the patient suddenly lost feeling on the radial side of the forearm. What nerve was injured?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

During IV cannulation in the median cubital vein, the lateral antebrachial cutaneous nerve can be injured due to its proximity, especially if the needle is inserted too deeply or laterally, causing numbness on the radial side of the forearm.

  • The lateral antebrachial cutaneous nerve is the terminal sensory branch of the musculocutaneous nerve.
  • It emerges lateral to the biceps tendon near the cubital fossa and provides cutaneous sensation to the radial (lateral) side of the forearm.
  • If the needle goes a bit medial, it could injure the medial antebrachial cutaneous nerve, which is a direct branch of the medial cord of the brachial plexus; it innervates skin on the medial side of the forearm. (Option B)
  • If the needle goes too deep, the median nerve might be injured.
  • Musculocutaneous nerve: While this nerve gives rise to the lateral antebrachial cutaneous branch, it is deeper and not directly at risk during a superficial venipuncture. (Option C)
  • The posterior antebrachial cutaneous nerve is a branch of the radial nerve that supplies the posterior forearm. (Option D)
  • The superficial radial nerve is a terminal branch of the radial nerve, which supplies the dorsum of the hand and the dorsal side of the lateral 2.5 digits.
  • Neither of these nerves would be affected by a venipuncture in the median cubital fossa.

questions.text: A man is brought to the ER with a stab wound just below and medial to the coracoid process. He has lost a lot of bright red blood from a large (~1.2 cm in diameter) severed artery found deep at this location. During surgery, the doctor cuts through the clavicular head of the pectoralis major to access the area. He then finds a partially severed muscle running downward and medially from the coracoid process, which he divides for better exposure. Which was the partially severed muscle from the given image?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pectoralis minor (C) inserts on the coracoid process of the scapula. Its origin is ribs 3-5, so it runs downward and medially from the coracoid process.

choices.text: Fibrous stroma is absent beneath the areola
Alveolar epithelium is columnar in the resting phase
15-20 lactiferous ducts open in the nipple
Myoepitheliocytes facilitate the passage of the milk along the ducts

questions.text: Which of the following statements about breast tissue is false?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Alveolar epithelium is cuboidal in the resting phase, and columnar during lactation. So, Option B is a false statement.

The fibrous stroma forms septa (suspensory ligaments of Cooper), which anchor the skin and gland to the pectoral fascia.

Explanation for other options:

Fibrous stroma is absent beneath the areola (Option A): Beneath the areola, the fibrous (supportive) stroma is replaced by smooth muscle fibres to aid in nipple erection.

15-20 lactiferous ducts open in the nipple (Option C): Each lobe of the breast has a lactiferous duct, typically 15-20 in number, that opens at the nipple surface.

Myoepitheliocytes facilitate the passage of milk along the ducts (Option D): Myoepithelial cells, located between the epithelium and basement membrane, contract in response to oxytocin, aiding in milk ejection.

choices.text: Branches of the lateral thoracic vein
Lymphatic vessels draining into the axilla

questions.text: A woman with breast cancer subsequently develops metastases in her vertebral column. Which is the most direct route for the spread of the tumour to the vertebral column?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most likely route for the cancer to reach the vertebral column is through the intercostal veins, i.e. hematogenous spread.

  • The intercostal veins, especially the posterior intercostal veins, drain into the azygos and hemiazygos system.
  • These veins communicate with the vertebral venous plexus (Batson’s plexus), a valveless network of veins that runs along the vertebral column.
  • Because this system is valveless, it allows retrograde flow, especially during increased intra-abdominal or intrathoracic pressure.
  • This enables breast cancer cells to spread directly to the vertebrae, bypassing the lymph nodes or superficial veins.

Explanation for other options:

The cephalic vein and thoracoacromial vein would not be draining the breast, and the lateral thoracic vein would not be directing blood toward the vertebral column. (Option A and B)

Lymphatic vessels will lead to axillary nodes, not directly to vertebrae; metastasis via lymphatics usually affects lymph nodes first. (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

The Batson's vertebral venous plexus is a common route for metastatic spread of cancers (e.g., breast, prostate) to the spine and skull, due to its valveless, low-resistance nature.

questions.text: The clavipectoral fascia is penetrated by which artery?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The thoracoacromial artery pierces the clavipectoral fascia and gives off four branches,

Structures that pierce the clavipectoral fascia:

  1. Cephalic vein
  2. Thoracoacromial artery (a branch of the axillary artery)
  3. Lateral pectoral nerve
  4. Lymphatics from the breast

Explanation for other options:

Anterior circumflex humeral (Option A): Encircles the surgical neck of the humerus; does not pierce the fascia

Axillary artery (Option B): Lies deep but does not pierce the clavipectoral fascia

Subscapular artery (Option C): A branch of the 3rd part of the axillary artery, runs posteriorly.

questions.text: Match the following muscles and their radial nerve supply levels
questions.solution:
• The radial nerve gives out muscular branches to supply the long head, medial head, and lateral head of the triceps brachii muscles before and during its course in the radial sulcus.
  • After it emerges from the radial sulcus, it supplies the brachialis, brachioradialis and extensor carpi radialis longus.

questions.text: In the following fracture, which muscle is spared?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

In humeral shaft fractures involving the spiral groove segment, the triceps and anconeus are usually spared.

Radial Nerve Injury at the Spiral Groove

Structures Typically Spared:

  • Triceps brachii (long & medial heads): Motor branches arise proximal to the spiral groove
  • Anconeus: Supplied just above the groove's distal end
  • Posterior cutaneous nerve of the arm: Sensory branch given off before entering the groove

Structures Commonly Affected:

  • Brachioradialis: Weak forearm flexion (especially in mid-prone position) (Option A)
  • Wrist extensors (ECRL, ECRB, ECU): Lead to wrist drop
  • Supinator: Weak supination (biceps compensates) (Option C)
  • Finger & thumb extensors (EDC, EPL, EPB, EI): Inability to extend MCP joints and thumb (Option D)

choices.text: The pectoralis major is the superiormost and largest muscle of the anterior chest wall
It is a thick, fan-shaped muscle that lies underneath the breast tissue and forms the anterior wall of the axilla.
Flexion, adduction and medial rotation of the arm at the glenohumeral joint
The clavicular head causes extension of the flexed arm.

questions.text: All of the following are true about the pectoralis major except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clavicular head causes flexion of the extended arm. So, Option D is incorrect.

questions.text: Which of the following is related to the fracture shown below?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The surgical neck extends from just distal to the tuberosities to the shaft of the humerus. The axillary nerve and circumflex humeral vessels lie against the bone here. The proximal aspect of the humerus. Note the greater and lesser tuberosities as the site of attachment for muscles.

questions.text: Which statement is false regarding abduction of the arm?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The posterior deltoid primarily assists in extension and lateral rotation, not abduction. The medial (middle) deltoid is the key abductor in the 30-90° range.

  • 0-15° : Supraspinatus initiates abduction
  • 15-90°: Medial fibres of the deltoid continue abduction
  • >90°: Upper trapezius and serratus anterior aid in scapular rotation
  • 30-40 °: medial deltoid

questions.text: Identify the muscle responsible for radial deviation.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The flexor carpi radialis muscle flexes the hand at the wrist and provides radial deviation of the hand at the wrist, as well as helps to pronate the forearm.

questions.text: Which of the following ligaments does not directly contribute to stabilising the shoulder joint?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The coracoacromial ligament forms a protective arch above the shoulder joint but does not stabilise the joint capsule itself.

Explanation for other options:

Glenohumeral ligaments (superior, middle, inferior) (Option A): Reinforce the anterior capsule of the shoulder joint.

Coracohumeral ligament (Option B): Supports the superior aspect of the joint capsule.

Transverse humeral ligament (Option D): Holds the long head of the biceps tendon in the bicipital groove (indirect support).
